{{Frame |Name gloss=educational deprivation |Description=systematic depriv. of education |Comments=In modern day Iran, various groups--ethnic, religious and ideological--have been deprived from secondary or higher education by the regime. These groups include the Baha'is of Iran--the biggest religious minority in the country--Afghan residents of Iran--most of whom fled Afghanistan following the Soviet occupation of their country in 1979--as well as ethnic "minorities" of Iran--Kurdish, . Arab, Baluchi--who are deprived of education due to poverty, unemployment and language barrier (native language is spoken at home until students enter the educational system exclusively taught in standard Persian). Reports suggest that more than 50 percent of Arab-Iranians drop out of high school |Family=طرح های دسترسی به تحصیلات |Status=in development |Last reviewed by=Aria Fani |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs={{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=محرومیت آموزشی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=محرومیت از تحصیل }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=حق تحصیل }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=احکام تعلیق }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=ستاره دار }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=محرومیت از تحصیلات عالی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=جلوگیری از ورود به دانشگاه }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=اخراج }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=پاکسازی دانشگاه ها }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=محرومین از تحصیل }} |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=Violation |Comments=The word khalaf has a wide semantic field in Persian. It could mean "opposition" (khalaf or mukhalefat karadan: demonstrate disagreement), deceit (khalaf-gu: lier, deceit-sayer), criminal (khalaf-kar: violation-doer), antagonistic (khalaf-e haq: antagonistic towards justice), immoral (khalaf-e shar': violation of sharia, Muslim ethics and laws. {{Frame |Name gloss=Democracy |Description=Democracy - Persian neologism |Comments=We have three frames for democracy as of now, one is dimukrasi, the Western loanword, the second is ardum-salari, the Persian neologism that closely approximates the concept of democracy, and the last is mardum-salari-i dini, or the concept of religous democracy based on Islamic values and principles. Perhas, one could argue that the last notion is distinct enough in the Persian conext to warrn its separate existence but the other two are used interchangably. We need to discuss in our next meeting whether we would like to keep the first two together or merge them
|Family=طرح دموکراسی‌, طرح حکومت, |Type=Frame |Status=in development |Entered by=Reza |Last reviewed by=Aria Fani, |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs={{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاری }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالار }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاري دیني }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاري }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسي }} |LinkEnglish=Democracy |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=(zaman(time |Type=Frame |Cultural information=Historically and in poetry and philosophy, Zaman refers to the inevitable flow of time which has no beginning or end. It is the external physical entity, which by the folk theory of objective reality causes change, aging, and death; and thereby limits our reality. In Rumi and Molana, vaght refers to a person's experience of time. For example, someone may experience an extended perceived time (vaght) with respect to the physical time (zaman) which may go by more or less quickly than physical time. In modern day usage, vaght and zaman overlap in many, but not all cases. The frames evoked are distinct. Zaman is used to refer to longer and more general periods of time and time as well as time in the physical sense. Vaght refers to precise periods/moments in time and to shorter periods of time.
ای زمین بی من مرو و ای زمان بی من مرو/ای فلک بی من مگرد و ای قمر بی من متاب |Status=in development, proposed |Entered by=Sanam, Aria |Roles= |Related frames={{Related frame |Related frame.Relation type=is somehow related to |Related frame.Name=وقت |Related frame.Description= The english word Time encompasses all cases of vaght and zaman }} |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |Applicability=Persian }}

Zaman is used to refer to longer and more general periods of time and time as well as time in the physical sense. Vaght refers to precise periods/moments in time and to shorter periods of time.

revision.text: {{Frame |Comments=The frame for afat differs from that of parasite. A salient example of afat is the parasite Aphid, which is known to ruin crops. In the target domain of this metaphor it is understood that the damager is an invader which is not immediately detected. Lexical entries which involve the afat frame include: |Type=Frame |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Comments=The frame for afat differs from that of parasite. A salient example of afat is the parasite Aphid, which is known to ruin crops. In the target domain of this metaphor it is understood that the damager is an invader which is not immediately detected. Lexical entries which involve the afat frame include: |Type=Frame |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |Applicability=Persian }} آفت در و دین در شعر، معشوقی سخت جمیل.
و آرمی آن روز که در رحم نطفه گردد تا آخر عمر یک لحظه از آفت نرهذ.
آسیب کشت را رسه، سن، تگرگا، شته، مرق، صاعقه، سیل.
عصبانیت و غرور آفت زندگی مشترک است.
مدرک گرایی در بازار کار آفت آموزشها محمارتی.
شاه بی بخشش آفت سپه

{{Frame |Comments=The frame for afat differs from that of parasite. A salient example of afat is the parasite Aphid, which is known to ruin crops. In the target domain of this metaphor it is understood that the damager is an invader which is not immediately detected. Lexical entries which involve the afat frame include: |Type=Frame |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |Applicability=Persian }} آفت دل و دین در شعر، معشوقی سخت جمیل است.
و آدمی آن روز که در رحم، نطفه گردد تا آخر عمر یک لحظه از آفت نرهد.
آسیب که کشت را رسد، ملخ، سن، تگرگ، شته، برق، صاعقه، سیل.
عصبانیت و غرور، آفت زندگی مشترک است.
مدرک گرایی در بازار کار آفت آموزشهای مهارتی است.
شاه بی بخشش آفت سپه است (بی نیازی سپاه، دل شه است).
من دنیا را بران چاه پرآفت مانند کردم.
دوٍستیِّت مبار با نادان که بود دوستیِّش آفت جان.

{{Frame |Name gloss=leader |Comments=Closest corresponding English frame is: state leadership |Type=Frame |Cultural information=The Persian word "rahbar" is a broad term for leader used in various contexts, after the Iranian Revolution of 1979 the term has come to refer to the office of the Ayatollah. The phrase "rahbar-i inqilab" [leader of the revolution] refers to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The official office of Ayatollah Khameni, the current leader of the Islamic Republic is: daftar-i maqam-i mu'azam-i rahbari, lit. the office of the exalted figure of leadership. revision.text: {{Frame |Name gloss=democracy |Family=طرح دموکراسی‌, |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |LinkEnglish=Democracy |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=Democracy |Other aliases=مردم سالاری |Comments=The Persian term mardum-sālāri (lit. people-dominance) has been coined as an equivalent for democracy, which has gained currency in recent decades. Based on the team’s investigation thus far, mardum-sālāri does not seem to depart ideologically from the main pillars of democracy; however blogs/websites written within Iran (affiliated with the system or cultural entities) have shown a strong preference for the Persian term, rather than the loanword dimukrasi. Many writers maintain that concepts developed and propagated in the West need to develop organically according to the cultural values and norms of other cultures, the use of a Persian term for democracy is at times perceived as a first step in this direction. |Family=طرح دموکراسی‌, |Type=Frame |Cultural information=In the political discourse of the Islamic Republic, a term that has also gained currency in recent years is mardum-sālāri-yi dini (religious democracy). This concept gives precedence to Divine ruling; the interests of the masses are determined by the representatives of the Divine rule (positions not elected by the people include the office of the Ayatollah and members of the Guardianship of Islamic Jurists), a select number of these representatives (President, members of the Iranian majlis, etc) are elected by the people. The concept of religious democracy is being further investigated. |Status=in development |Entered by=Reza |Last reviewed by=Aria Fani, |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs={{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی‌ }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی ها }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاری }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراتیک }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی خواهی‌ }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار کردن }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار کرد }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار می‌کند }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار خواهد کرد }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=عرصه ی دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=خرد جمعی‌ دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی طلبانه }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی اصلاح طلبانه }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مرکز دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=خواست پیشبرد دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دمکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی دینی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاری دینی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian }} |LinkEnglish=Democracy |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=Democracy |Other aliases=مردم سالاری |Comments=The Persian term mardum-sālāri (lit. people-dominance) has been coined as an equivalent for democracy, which has gained currency in recent decades. Based on the team’s investigation thus far, mardum-sālāri does not seem to depart ideologically from the main pillars of democracy; however blogs/websites written within Iran (affiliated with the system or cultural entities) have shown a strong preference for the Persian term, rather than the loanword dimukrasi. Many writers maintain that concepts developed and propagated in the West need to develop organically according to the cultural values and norms of other cultures, the use of a Persian term for democracy is at times perceived as a first step in this direction. |Family=طرح دموکراسی‌, |Type=Frame |Cultural information=In the political discourse of the Islamic Republic, a term that has also gained currency in recent years is mardum-sālāri-yi dini (religious democracy). This concept gives precedence to Divine ruling; the interests of the masses are determined by the representatives of the Divine rule (positions not elected by the people include the office of the Ayatollah and members of the Guardianship of Islamic Jurists), a select number of these representatives (President, members of the Iranian majlis, etc) are elected by the people. The concept of religious democracy is being further investigated. |Status=in development |Entered by=Reza |Last reviewed by=Aria Fani, |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs={{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی‌ }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی ها }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاری }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراتیک }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی خواهی‌ }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار کردن }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار کرد }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار می‌کند }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی برقرار خواهد کرد }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=عرصه ی دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=خرد جمعی‌ دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی طلبانه }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی اصلاح طلبانه }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مرکز دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=خواست پیشبرد دموکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دمکراسی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=دموکراسی دینی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاری دینی }}{{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=حکومت قاطبه مردم }} |LinkEnglish=Democracy |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=Democracy |Other aliases=مردم سالاری |Comments=The Persian term mardum-sālāri (lit. people-dominance) has been coined as an equivalent for democracy, which has gained currency in recent decades. Based on the team’s investigation thus far, mardum-sālāri does not seem to depart ideologically from the main pillars of democracy; however blogs/websites written within Iran (affiliated with the system or cultural entities) have shown a strong preference for the Persian term, rather than the loanword dimukrasi. {{Frame |Name gloss=Democracy |Description=Democracy -loanword |Other aliases=مردم سالاری |Comments=The Persian term mardum-sālāri (lit. people-dominance) has been coined as an equivalent for democracy, which has gained currency in recent decades. Based on the team’s investigation thus far, mardum-sālāri does not seem to depart ideologically from the main pillars of democracy; however blogs/websites written within Iran (affiliated with the system or cultural entities) have shown a strong preference for the Persian term, rather than the loanword dimukrasi. Many writers maintain that concepts developed and propagated in the West need to develop organically according to the cultural values and norms of other cultures, the use of a Persian term for democracy is at times perceived as a first step in this direction.
We have three frames for democracy as of now, one is dimukrasi, the Western loanword, the second is ardum-salari, the Persian neologism that closely approximates the concept of democracy, and the last is mardum-salari-i dini, or the concept of religous democracy based on Islamic values and principles. Perhas, one could argue that the last notion is distinct enough in the Persian conext to warrn its separate existence but the other two are used interchangably. We need to discuss in our next meeting whether we would like to keep the first two together or merge them |Family=طرح دموکراسی‌ |Type=Frame |Cultural information=In the political discourse of the Islamic Republic, a term that has also gained currency in recent years is mardum-sālāri-yi dini (religious democracy). {{Frame |Name gloss=(vaght (time |Cultural information=خوشتر ز عیش و صحبت و باغ و بهار چیست / ساقی کجاست گو سبب انتظارچیست هر وقت خوش که دست دهد مغتنم شمار/ کس را وقوف نیست که انجام کار چیست |Status=in development |Entered by=Aria and Sanam |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=(vaght (time |Type=Frame |Cultural information=Historically and in poetry and philosophy, Zaman refers to the inevitable flow of time which has no beginning or end. It is the external physical entity, which by the folk theory of objective reality causes change, aging, and death; and thereby limits our reality. In Rumi and Molana, vaght refers to a person's experience of time. For example, someone may experience an extended perceived time (vaght) with respect to the physical time (zaman) which may go by more or less quickly than physical time. In contemporary usage, vaght and zaman overlap in many, but not all cases. The frames evoked are distinct. Zaman is used to refer to longer and more general periods of time and time as well as time in the physical sense. Vaght refers to precise periods/moments in time and to shorter periods of time.
خوشتر ز عیش و صحبت و باغ و بهار چیست / ساقی کجاست گو سبب انتظارچیست هر وقت خوش که دست دهد مغتنم شمار/ کس را وقوف نیست که انجام کار چیست |Status=in development |Entered by=Aria, Sanam |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |Applicability=Persian }}

revision.comment: Aria صفحهٔ [[وقت]] را به [[Frame:وقت]] منتقل کرد
revision.text:
{{Frame |Name gloss=(vaght (time |Type=Frame |Cultural information=Historically and in poetry and philosophy, Zaman refers to the inevitable flow of time which has no beginning or end. It is the external physical entity, which by the folk theory of objective reality causes change, aging, and death; and thereby limits our reality. In Rumi and Molana, vaght refers to a person's experience of time. For example, someone may experience an extended perceived time (vaght) with respect to the physical time (zaman) which may go by more or less quickly than physical time. In contemporary usage, vaght and zaman overlap in many, but not all cases. The frames evoked are distinct. Zaman is used to refer to longer and more general periods of time and time as well as time in the physical sense. Vaght refers to precise periods/moments in time and to shorter periods of time.
خوشتر ز عیش و صحبت و باغ و بهار چیست / ساقی کجاست گو سبب انتظارچیست هر وقت خوش که دست دهد مغتنم شمار/ کس را وقوف نیست که انجام کار چیست |Status=in development |Entered by=Aria, Sanam |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs= |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=democracy religious |Description=Religious democracy |Comments=The English frame, 'democracy' broadly corresponds with this frame |Family=طرح دموکراسی‌, |Type=Frame |Cultural information=In the political discourse of the Islamic Republic, a term that has also gained currency in recent years is mardum-sālāri-yi dini (religious democracy). This concept gives precedence to Divine ruling; the interests of the masses are determined by the representatives of the Divine rule (positions not elected by the people include the office of the Ayatollah and members of the Guardianship of Islamic Jurists), a select number of these representatives (President, members of the Iranian majlis, etc) are elected by the people. The concept of religious democracy is being further investigated.
|Status=in development |Entered by=Reza |Last reviewed by=Aria Fani, |Roles= |Related frames= |Bindings= |Inferences= |Relevant LUs={{LUs |LUs.Language=Persian |LUs.Lemmas=مردم سالاری دینی }} |LinkEnglish=Democracy |Applicability=Persian }}

{{Frame |Name gloss=bureaucracy |Description=bureaucracy -loanword |Comments=As of now, we have two frames and frame families for bureaucracy, one for the Western loanword and the other its Persian neologism. Both terms are used interchangeably and extensively in Persian-language blogs, the Persian neologism is favored more in official writings. We have not concluded yet any reasons to warrant the existence of two frames for the same concept. All the same both frames are inter-connected and appear under the frame families as well. We need to discuss this in our upcoming meeting.
